Award.AwardTitle: The 4th Workshop on Sustainable Software for Science: Best Practices and Experiences (WSSSPE4)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the attendance at WSSSPE4 (4th Workshop on Sustainable Software for Science: Best Practices and Experiences) for US based researchers, particularly targeted at encouraging attendance by early stage researchers with attention to diversity. The WSSSPE4 workshop is part of a community driven effort to address the many new challenges that are evident for the development, deployment, maintenance, and sustainability of reusable software for academic research and education. These challenges include the software development process; the support and maintenance of software; governance and business models particularly for sustainability; the role of software in building science communities; the need for software to lead to science which is verifiable and reproducible; policy issues such as how to measure software impact, choose licensing, or assign software credit; and the education and nurturing of early stage researchers in scientific software. Based on successful WSSSPE1-WSSSPE3 meetings at SC13, SC14, and NCAR in 2013, 2014, and 2015, the organizers expect over 60 submitted papers and around 75 attendees at the WSSSPE4 meeting. WSSSPE4 accepted submission would be published as a special collection in http://ceur-ws.org/, which is fully indexed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the WSSSPE4 workshop, which is part of a community driven effort to address the many new challenges that are evident for the development, deployment, maintenance, and sustainability of reusable software for academic research and education. These challenges include the software development process, the support and maintenance of software, governance and business models particularly for sustainability, the role of software in building science communities, the need for software to lead to science which is verifiable and reproducible, policy issues such as how to measure software impact, choose licensing, or assign software credit, and the education and nurturing of early stage researchers in scientific software. The workshop was based on successful WSSSPE1–WSSSPE3 meetings at SC13, SC14, and NCAR in 2013, 2014, and 2015.

The workshop had 68 attendees. Accepted submissions to WSSSPE4 comprised 19 lightning talks, 4 idea papers, 3 position papers, 2 experience papers, and 3 demos. The papers and lightning talks have been published as a volume in the CEUR Workshop Proceedings: Allen G, Carver J, Choi SCT, Crick T, Crusoe MR, Gesing S, et al., editors. Proceedings of the Fourth Workshop on Sustainable Software for Science: Practice and Experiences (WSSSPE4). Aachen; 2016. Urn:nbn:de:0074-1686-8. Available from: http://ceur-ws.org/Vol-1686/.

WSSSPE4 was held immediately preceding the RSE (Research Software Engineer) Conference in Manchester, UK, in September 2016. As with previous events, WSSSPE4 provided an open and dynamic forum for the community to discuss experiences and approaches in the areas listed above.

This project funded attendance at WSSSPE4 for US based researchers, particularly targeted at encouraging attendance by early stage researchers with attention to diversity.  The NSF funds, combined with additional funds from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and the Software Sustainability Institute (SSI) supported the travel of participants who would not otherwise have been able to attend the workshop. These funds allowed 29 additional people to attend and participate, including four undergraduate and seven graduate students and five early-career researchers. 12 workshop attendees were female, and attendees were from about 10 countries.

The funded participants were selected using a formal application procedure, with selection criteria based around (1) the potential of their attendance to contribute towards their own research and educational goals; (2) their potential contribution to the workshop; (3) providing a diverse set of attendees with priority to early stage researchers (e.g., students, postdoctoral researchers, early stage faculty). The workshop included vision and position papers as well as lightning talks and demos, aimed at improving sustainable scientific software today as well as defining and working towards the its future.

The WSSSPE4 report has been published on arxiv (https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.02607), and a version has been submitted to the Journal of Open Research Software, along with extended versions of individual WSSSPE4 accepted papers and lightning talks.
